title.narrative: Health and rights for People Who Use Drugs in Georgia

description.narrative: The programme aims to end the AIDS epidemic among PWUD in Georgia through 1) a strenghtened civil society that holds governments to account, 2) increased fullfilment of human rights of key populations, 3) improved SRHR and fewer infections. The specific outcomes include: - increased awaraness of PWUD community of their SRHR and available services - CSOs have strengthened skills and knowledge on protecting rights and working with the government. Standards and systems of monitoring the quality of services exist, and data on effectiveness of interventions and services are available for activists. -Healthcare and law enforcement professionals have continuous education to build non-stigmatising attitudes. Professional standards are elaborated and approved. -Community representatives actively protect their rights, with the support of civil society organisations and human rights defenders. -Society is tolerant and informed about the needs and problems of PWUD. Mass media provides correct and tolerant information on drug use, and issues of SRHR are integrated into the general education. - Community initiatives and KP activists are involved in influencing the government through an established mechanism. -A supportive policy environment exists, with the political will to initiate (liberal) legislation changes, and to involve civil society organisations and key populations. Services and NGOs are supported with financially by the government, international donors and social enterprises to ensure sustainability. Services are accessible and affordable (including rehabilitation and employment)

We believe that the end of AIDS is possible if there is more focus on key populations. Our project in Georgia addresses barriers faced by the PWUD community related to their sexual and reproductive health and rights. Driven by community champions, we work to realize PWUD activists and community initiatives are able to influence the government through an established mechanism; a supportive policy environment exists with the political will to change legislation and to meaningfully involve civil society and PWUD; and service delivery done by NGOs is financed by the government and international donors. Georgia is among low HIV prevalence countries being at high risk for an expanding epidemic due to widespread injecting drug use and the population movement between Georgia and neighbouring high HIV prevalence countries such as Ukraine and Russia. Since 1997 the number of newly registered cases started to increase and Georgia is one of those very few countries in the world and in the region where the HIV incidence has been increasing steadily during the last decade. The latest available evidence indicate that the HIV epidemic in Georgia is largely concentrated among key populations, including PWUD for which the estimated HIV prevalence is 2.2%. Another major problem is the late HIV diagnosis and its association with a high mortality rate and the major multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB burden. Despite the impressive expansion of HIV prevention efforts over the last several years, coverage of key populations with preventive services and HIV testing remains low for all key populations. It should be highlighted that the state programme does not procure 4th generation HIV tests, which identify HIV positive cases earlier. There are no services addressing the specific needs of young people (between the ages of 14 and 24) who are vulnerable and most at risk of HIV in Georgia. Stigma and discrimination of people living with HIV continues to be a major barrier to HIV prevention and service utilisation. Negative social attitudes and low public awareness also remain obstacles, especially for PWUD. Besides societal attitudes, state criminal laws, regulations, and policies relevant to drug use and preventive work among IDUs and prisoners are among limiting factors. Despite the accomplishments in various areas of national HIV response, the epidemic continues to grow.
We focus on People Who Use Drugs. So far, 12 peers and 20 professionals have been trained and 1300 clients reached, of which 300 receive the full package of services.

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

title.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

comment.narrative: With little trust from People Who Use Drugs (PWUD) in medical workers, trainings aim at reducing stigma and discrimination among service providers. Results of monitoring reveal trainings with law enforcement professionals and medical staff have contributed to an increase in knowledge and affect attitudes towards PWUD.

title.narrative: 6 Global level advocacy tools campaigns and resources developed

description.narrative: Number of Global level advocacy tools campaigns and resources developed

title.narrative: 6 # of global-level advocacy tools, campaigns and resources

description.narrative: 6 # of global-level advocacy tools, campaigns and resources. Number of tools campaigns or resources developed

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services

description.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services (disaggregated by age) everything falling under voluntary counselling and testing is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

In Georgia, medical services are not free and without a medical insurance it is problematic to receive specific treatments for people who use drugs (PWUD). A wide range of health services provided at social bureaus and offered to PWUD such as liver examinations, consultations with a hepatologist and neurologist, and drug testing for hepatitis C and B. The availability of medical services is highly evaluated by clients.

title.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services

description.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services (disaggregated by age) ART, STI and TB treatment

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (condom distribution)

description.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (disaggregated by age) (condom distribution)

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services

description.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services (disaggregated by age) including self-help groups, psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services

description.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services (disaggregated by age)

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

description.narrative: Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services
2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services
